Description: An ivory or bone bead: in the form of a serekh, with the Horus falcon on the top, probably intended for use in a bracelet. The panels of the façade and the dots above are carved in sunken relief. The bead is pierced horizontally by two holes. The ivory is well preserved, although the object has been restored from three fragments, and the face of the hawk is missing.
Curator's comments: Serekhs occur as beads in bracelets of contemporary date and varied materials: gold and turquoise serekhs were found on the arm of a queen of Djer (see W. M. F. Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II (London, 1901), pl. I, no. 1 = E. Vernier, ‘Bijoux et orfèvreries. Catalogue général des antiquites égyptiennes du Musée du Caire’ (Cairo, 1927), no. 52008); blue glazed composition serekhs were found in a First Dynasty mastaba at Giza ( W. M. F. Petrie, 'Gizeh and Rifeh' (Warminster, 1977), pl. III = University College, London 25976 and W. S. Smith, ‘Ancient Egypt as Represented in the Museum of Fine Arts’, 1st ed., 19 and 4th ed., 24 = Boston MFA 07.565, from mastaba V at Giza. Also from this tomb: amuletic fragment (1901,1012.26). Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II (London, 1901), 17. Compare the bracelet also discovered in the tomb of Djer, illustrated in W. M. F. Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II (London, 1901), pl.I, 1; A. Wilkinson, 'Ancient Egyptian Jewellery' (London, 1971), 16, fig. 8. See also W. M. F. Petrie, 'Gizeh and Rifeh' (Warminster, 1977), pl.III, top right.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (198)
Condition: incomplete - one bead only. Ivory well-preserved
